By your logic, it sounds as though one might as well do away with the
protected keyword, as well as default package access behavior.  That is, you
are saying that if class A's methods are accessible to members of its
package and subclasses or only its package, then what the programmer should
do is define the methods of class A as public.  You said that "if the client
has no business touching these parts, make them private."  But we should say
that while a client can be an unknown, external process or third party
library, a client can also be a class in the same package of our own
library.  The existence of the various access modifiers gives us finer
control than the binary choice of public/private.

Scott Stirling
JRun QA
Macromedia

> IMO...
> 
>     > It simply make testing easier, without changing the 
> protection of
> existing code. 
>     > We find it sometimes easy to test part of a flow (which usually
> resides in a separate method) rather than 
>     > check the public interface function. 
> 
> Then shouldn't these be made part of the public interface and 
> allow the
> client to interact with them?  If the client has no business 
> touching these
> parts, make them private.
> 
>     > Also, I take the term "public interface" as relative. 
> If an object
> exposes an interface (set of methods)
>     > to its peer objects within its package, I see no reason 
> not to test
> it, even though those methods are
>     > package-protected. 
> 
> I guess I disagree here.  I am not convinced that 
> package-potected methods
> are part of a public interface.  If they are used that way I 
> would question
> whether some refactoring needed to take place.  But that's 
> just my opinion.
> I don't want to seem like I am picking on your design decisions.
> 
> -Jason
